title: Poppers: Side Effects, Uses, and Risks of Amyl Nitrite
author: Keri Wiginton, Alexandra Benisek

sections.heading: What Are Poppers Used For?
content: Poppers are a group of chemicals that people breathe in (inhale) to get high. These “party drugs” are typically made with amyl nitrite or a similar substance. People sniff nitrite vapors to get a fast feeling of euphoria or muscle relaxation, often during sex.
Poppers may be sold as leather cleaner, nail polish remover, or liquid incense. (Photo credit: Science Source)
Nitrites are a type of chemical that doctors sometimes use to treat heart conditions or chest pain. “Poppers” is a slang term for this type of chemical when it ’ s used recreationally.
Poppers aren ’ t addictive, but they can lead to serious health problems or death.

Poppers are among many forms of recreational inhalants (drugs you breathe in). Others include nitrous oxide (“laughing gas”), “whippets” (a type of nitrous oxide used as a propellant in whipped cream dispensers), and solvents such as glue.
They usually come in tiny glass or plastic bottles similar in size to popular energy drink shots. The liquid inside may be clear, golden, or yellowish.
Some people say the strong-smelling odor is fruity, sickly sweet, or like dirty socks. Never put poppers in your mouth to taste or drink the liquid. The chemicals are poisonous.

sections.heading: How Do People Use Poppers?
content: Nitrites were first sold in tiny glass vials that people would squeeze until they “popped.” This would release the nitrite vapors into the air so people could inhale the fumes. That’s where the term “poppers” comes from.
Poppers often come with screw-top bottles now, but people still use the drugs by inhaling the nitrite gas through their nose or mouth.
People who use poppers may:
Never light a cigarette coated in nitrites. Poppers are flammable, and you could burn yourself if the chemical catches fire.

sections.heading: Are Poppers Illegal?
content: You can legally buy or sell nitrites in the U.S., but it’s illegal for you to take or misuse them as a recreational drug. The FDA does not regulate poppers, but it warns against buying or using these products for fun.

You may get into legal trouble if you knowingly sell or supply poppers to people for recreational use, especially if they’re younger than 18 years. The offense depends on which state you live in, but you could go to jail and/or have to pay a fine if you’re found guilty of encouraging inhalant use.

sections.heading: What Are Poppers Used For?
content: The chemicals found in poppers belong to a class of drugs called alkyl nitrites. This includes amyl nitrite, butyl nitrite, isobutyl nitrite, isopropyl nitrite, and cyclohexyl nitrite.
In the medical world, amyl nitrite is a vasodilator (a drug that opens your blood vessels). It lowers your blood pressure and raises your heart rate.

Doctors may prescribe it to ease angina (chest pain, tightness, or squeezing). To use this medication, you crush a cloth-covered glass capsule between your thumb and finger, wave it back and forth near your nose, and inhale the vapor one to six times. You may faint or feel dizzy afterward.

In recreational use, people do poppers to feel a rush of euphoria or excitement , boost their skin’s sensations, and relax their muscles. The drugs work very quickly. They dilate your blood vessels, sending blood to your brain and boosting your heart rate.
Often, you’ll find them in places such as gas stations, sex shops, smoke shops, bars, nightclubs, or adult novelty stores. But many online and in-person stores sell poppers.

sections.heading: Poppers and the LGBTQ community
content: While it’s not illegal to sell the chemicals in poppers, the products are usually marketed as something else other than recreational drugs.
Poppers may be sold as:
You may also hear poppers called:

Poppers have been a popular party drug in the gay and queer community dating back to the 1970s. The drugs not only give you a brief high feeling but also can relax the muscles in your anus and vagina, which can make penetrative sex more comfortable and pleasurable.

The LGBTQ+ community pushed back when Australia’s Therapeutic Goods Administration proposed a ban on poppers. They felt that the law unfairly targeted gay men. That’s because men who have sex with other men sometimes use these drugs to make receiving anal sex (bottoming) less painful.

sections.heading: What is chemsex?
content: Because of the protests, the Australian government reversed its decision to ban amyl nitrite except as a prescription medication.
But in 2013, Canada successfully banned the sale of poppers for recreational use. Some see this decision as discriminatory toward gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men.
“Poppers have a long history of being demonized, but they remain a staple in the gay male population,” says Jeremy Prillwitz, a licensed advanced alcohol and drug counselor in Sacramento, California.

This is a term that refers to using drugs to enhance your sex life. This practice is common among gay men or other people who have anal sex. Besides poppers, drugs commonly used during sex include methamphetamine (crystal meth), mephedrone (meth), GHB, and GBL (G).

Right after you breathe in the fumes, you might feel a head rush or wave of good feelings. That’s because poppers quickly widen your blood vessels and lower your blood pressure. Your heart rate speeds up to keep your blood flowing. These effects typically wear off after a few minutes.

sections.heading: How do poppers affect your sex life?
content: Common short-term effects include:

Typical short-term risks of poppers include headaches, nosebleeds, dizziness, and skin or eye irritation. Most unwanted side effects aren’t serious. “But dizziness can lead to passing out, which can cause head injuries or other medical consequences,” Prillwitz says.
Poppers may not directly improve your sexual performance, but they can change how sex feels. They can:
Some people say these effects make sex more enjoyable. But poppers can also make it harder to keep an erection.

It’s important to know that poppers work in a way that’s similar to erectile dysfunction drugs, such as avanafil (Stendra), sildenafil (Liqrev, Revatio, Viagra), tadalafil (Adcirca, Cialis), or vardenafil (Levitra, Staxyn). Never mix them. “The combination can lead to a rapid and dangerous drop in blood pressure,” Prillwitz says.

sections.heading: What Are the Side Effects of Poppers?
content: These effects create a “ rush ” feeling that can also make you dizzy or lightheaded. You may feel like you ’ re very drunk. The high lasts only a few seconds or minutes.
Because poppers also relax the muscles in your vagina and anus, some people use them during sex.
The “high” symptoms of poppers may include:
In addition to a high, the drug can cause side effects such as:
You could notice a skin rash, unusual sleepiness, or weakness. These symptoms aren’t usually dangerous, but get medical help right away if you have any of them after using poppers.
If you get the liquid from poppers on your skin, it can cause a chemical irritation or burn you. If this happens, flush the area with water right away and seek medical advice .

sections.heading: Poppers dosage
content: Poppers or other drugs that affect your mind may affect you differently depending on how you feel when you take them or who and what you’re around. This concept is called “set and setting.”
Here’s a breakdown of what those terms mean:
Set. This refers to your state of mind, mood, and what you expect to happen when you take poppers. Your experience may also be different depending on whether you’ve taken these kinds of drugs before.

Setting. Drugs may affect you differently depending on the people around you or where you take drugs. For example, is the setting loud or quiet? Are you somewhere familiar or new to you? Are you around friends or strangers?
These drugs aren’t regulated by the FDA, so there’s no safe dose to recommend. But many people get unwanted side effects (such as a headache) after two to four sniffs.
The effects usually set in right away, typically within seconds.

sections.heading: Long-term effects
content: Poppers are short-lived and typically last only a few minutes. But how long they’ll affect you may depend on many things, including your body size, exactly what’s in the drug, and whether you’ve used poppers before.

Most people who use poppers regularly don’t have permanent or serious health problems. But it’s possible to go through unwanted or harmful side effects if you inhale nitrites a lot. Some symptoms are mild, while others are more serious.
Frequent use of poppers may cause:

sections.heading: Are Poppers Dangerous?
content: The FDA doesn ’ t regulate poppers for recreational use , so you can never be sure what ’ s in them. It ’ s best to use nitrite drugs only when and as your doctor prescribes them.
If you use nitrite drugs outside of their intended medical use, b e aware of these risks:
bullets: Never swallow or eat the liquid. This can be fatal. It could also lead to blindness, brain damage, and organ failure. If you do ingest the liquid, call 911 or Poison Control right away.
Long-term use can harm your nose and lungs. Studies also show that the drug lowers your immune system health after many days of use.
Because poppers are highly flammable, keep them away from candles, cigarettes, and lighters.
Poppers open your blood vessels. This makes it easier to get an infection (including sexually transmitted diseases such as HIV).
If you have a suppressed immune system, heart problems, low or high blood pressure, a history of cerebral hemorrhaging, or anemia , poppers could lead to further health issues.
People who are pregnant should not use poppers.
Using poppers with other illicit drugs such as cocaine could heighten the drug ’ s risks.
Poppers affect your judgment, so you ’ re more likely to do unsafe things while you ’ re on them.

sections.heading: Medication interactions
content: Sometimes, inhaling the fumes can cause your heart to stop beating. This is called sudden sniffing death syndrome, and it can happen the first time you use poppers.

Don’t mix poppers with other drugs, including recreational drugs, prescription medication, or the kind you can buy over the counter. Polydrug use, or using more than one drug or type of drug at once, can be dangerous and hard to predict.
In particular, never use poppers with:

Erectile dysfunction medication. This includes drugs such as sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra), tadalafil (Adcirca, Cialis), or vardenafil (Levitra, Staxyn). This combination could cause your blood pressure to fall too fast and lead to stroke, heart attack, or death.

Stimulants. Drugs that boost your heart rate , including cocaine or other amphetamine-like stimulants, can make your heart work so hard that it stops. This is called cardiac arrest, and it can be fatal.

sections.heading: Can You Develop a Tolerance for Poppers?
content: Over time, you might need to use more poppers to feel the same effects. That’s because your brain gets used to how they work, and the signal they send inside your body gets weaker with repeated use.
So, even though you’re not getting a stronger high, you keep using more to try to feel what you felt the first time.

“That can become a kind of psychological addiction,” says Denis Antoine, MD, associate professor of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. “You’re just trying to chase the same high that you had at the beginning, which becomes more and more difficult.”

Poppers don’t work like drugs that trigger the brain’s reward system (such as opioids, alcohol, or benzos), so they don’t cause physical dependence. That means if you stop using them, you probably won’t have classic withdrawal symptoms.
But if you use poppers a lot, you might feel a dip in your mood or energy after stopping. That’s not true withdrawal; it’s more about missing the drug’s short-term effects.

If you notice you’re reaching for poppers more often, or they’ve become a regular part of sex or social time, consider talking to a doctor or substance use counselor. They can discuss other ways you can enjoy your sex or social life and may be able to give you tips on safer ways to use these drugs if you choose to continue to do so.

sections.heading: Poppers FAQs
content: The active chemical compound in poppers (alkyl nitrites) relaxes your involuntary smooth muscles. When you inhale nitrite vapors, the drug causes the walls of your blood vessels to widen. As a result, your blood pressure drops, and your heart rate speeds up.
Poppers usually refer to amyl nitrites or a class of drugs called alkyl nitrites. This group of chemicals commonly includes amyl nitrite, butyl nitrite, isobutyl nitrite, and isopropyl nitrite.

sections.heading: Do poppers show up on a drug test?
content: Poppers is the street name for a group of drugs (alkyl nitrites) people inhale to get high or make sex more comfortable.
Poppers usually don’t show up on standard drug tests — most don’t screen for alkyl nitrites. Even if they did, the chemicals usually break down too fast to show up on a blood or urine test.

Poppers usually don’t stay in your system for more than a day. The exact time depends on things such as your health and how much and how often you used. But your body starts to break down the chemicals quickly (within minutes) after you inhale them.

You might burn your skin and internal organs such as your stomach, or it may cause kidney damage. Swallowing alkyl nitrites can also lead to a life-threatening condition called methemoglobinemia, where your blood can’t carry oxygen properly. If you swallow poppers, call 911 or go to the emergency room right away. You may need fast treatment (usually with a medicine called methylene blue).
